metadata.title: Facile preparation of egg-shell-type pellet catalysts using immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent and hydrophilic solution: Enhancement of catalytic activity due to position control of metallic nickel inside alumina pellet

Facile preparation of egg-shell-type pellet catalysts using immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent and hydrophilic solution: Enhancement of catalytic activity due to position control of metallic nickel inside alumina pellet Min-Su Jang a 1 Eui Hyun Cho a 1 Kee Young Koo b Wang Lai Yoon b Chang Hyun Ko a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, Chonnam National University, 77, Youngbong-ro, Buk-gu, Gwangju, 61186, Republic of Korea School of Chemical Engineering Chonnam National University 77 Youngbong-ro Buk-gu Gwangju 500-757 Republic of Korea b Hydrogen Production Research Center, Korea Institute of Energy Research, 152, Gajeong-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon, 305-343, Republic of Korea Hydrogen Production Research Center Korea Institute of Energy Research 152 Gajeong-ro Yuseong-gu Daejeon 305-343 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this study. Graphical abstract Egg-shell-type catalysts, in which active components were selectively located outer region of pellet, have been prepared to effectively utilize catalytically active components in the reactions with high gas-hourly space velocity conditions. We developed a new and facile preparation method for egg-shell catalysts using immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent preoccupied inside pellet and aqueous hydrophilic precursor solution. A series of alcohols, propanol, butanol, pentanol and so on, were used as hydrophobic solvents to retard the penetration of aqueous metal precursor solutions. After drying solvents and proper calcination and reduction, catalytically active components, metallic nickel particles, were selectively located in the outer region of pellet. Owing to the selective deposition of metallic particles, the egg-shell catalysts showed higher conversion of methane in steam methane reforming than homo-type catalysts, which has homogeneous distribution of metal particles on the entire range of pellet, as the space velocity increased from 6000 to 30,000h−1. Keywords Selective deposition Egg-shell-type catalyst Immiscibility Alumina pellet Steam methane reforming 1 Introduction For the preparation of catalysts applicable for the industrial scale, catalytically active components, such as precious metals, should be highly dispersed on the porous and inert pellet supports in order to reduce pressure drop within fixed-bed reactors. In addition to pressure drop, the performance of supported catalyst can be controlled depending on the distribution of catalytically active components. The “egg-shell catalyst” can be defined that catalytically active metal nanoparticles were selectively distributed on the outer region inside pellet as egg-shell shape distribution instead of homogeneous distribution throughout pellet. This egg-shell shape distribution is expected to be desirable for the reactions with diffusion limitation [1,2], for example Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis [2]. For the preparation of egg-shell catalyst, the selection of precursors, the surface nature of support, impregnation conditions, subsequent treatment conditions should be controlled carefully [3]. Preparing egg-shell catalyst for platinum on γ-alumina is relatively easy because the most frequently used platinum precursor, H2PtC6, has strong interaction with the surface of γ-alumina [4]. Citric acid, various salts, and so on were used to control the distribution of platinum precursors on γ-alumina pellets [5–7]. In addition to platinum, chrome, copper, and nickel were impregnated on γ-alumina to prepare egg-shell catalysts. The concentrations of precursor solutions, immersion time, precursor solution volumes, and drying conditions were controlled to obtain egg-shell catalysts [8–11]. To achieve egg-shell catalysts, the concentration of precursor solution was limited to low concentration (less than 0.8M) mainly due to weak interaction between precursors and the surface of alumina. For the preparation of egg-shell catalysts with high metal loading, a new method to use high concentration metal precursor solutions (∼3M) should be developed. In case of using silica pellet, of which surface has also weak interaction with most of metal precursors, different types of impregnation methods have been applied. The diffusion of cobalt precursor [Co(NO3)2] inside silica pellet was controlled mainly by contact time and/or concentration [2]. Hollow silica was used as a support to obtain egg-shell distribution of metallic nickel [12] and platinum [13] particles. Air bubbles were trapped inside pellet prior to metal salt impregnation by hydrophobic silica surface to produce egg-shell catalyst of Co/SiO2 and Ir-ReOx/SiO2 [14,15]. Hydrocarbon solvent (n-heptane [16] or n-undecane [17]) were used as a blocking solvent to prevent the diffusion of cobalt nitrate aqueous solution into silica pellet. These methods successfully prepared egg-shell catalysts using silica pellet. However, these methods have not been applied to alumina pellet, which is also a useful pellet for industrial applications. In this study, a series of alcohols were used as the preventing solvents to retard diffusion of aqueous nickel precursor [Ni(NO3)2] with high concentration (3M) inside alumina pellet. Egg-shell catalyst of 5wt.% Ni/γ-alumina were prepared and this catalyst was compared with 5wt.% Ni/γ-alumina pellet catalyst with homogeneous distribution in steam methane reforming reaction. At high gas-hourly space velocity, 5wt.% Ni/γ-alumina pellet catalyst with homogeneous distribution lost its initial catalytic activity. However, egg-shell catalyst maintained its initial activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were used as received without further purification unless indicated otherwise. Alumina spherical pellet (γ-alumina, SASOL spheres 2.5/210) was purchased from SASOL. Absolute ethanol (99.5%), 1-propanol (99.7%), 1-butanol (99%), 1-pentanol (99%), 1-octanol (99%), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 98%), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 98.5%) were purchased from Aldrich. High purity hydrogen was purchased from Gaswell. The commercial nickel catalyst (FCR-4, Süd-chemie Catalysts Inc., 12wt.% Ni/α-Al2O3) was used as a standard catalyst for steam methane reforming for comparison. 2.2 Preparation of pellet catalysts The egg-shell catalyst, nickel or cobalt was selectively located in the outer region of alumina pellet, was prepared by the following procedure shown in Fig. 1 . Before preparation, alumina pellet was dried at 150°C for 2h. In the first step, alumina pellets were soaked in the hydrophobic solvents, such as ethanol, 1-propanol, 1-butanol, 1-pentanol, and 1-octanol. This step was taken for hydrophobic solvent to occupy pores inside alumina pellet. During this step, sonication had been done in order to completely fill the hydrophobic solvent in the entire pore of alumina pellets. The second step is introducing metal salts, for example, nickel nitrate or cobalt nitrate, by wet impregnation. The metal salt concentration was changed from 0.5, 1.0, and 3M. When the concentration of metal salt solution was 0.5M, the solution volume was 100mL for 5g of alumina pellet. When the metal salt concentration was 1.0 and 3.0M, the solution volume was 10mL for 5g of alumina pellet. The soaking time of metal salt solution also changed depending on metal salt concentration. In typical case, the soaking time was 3min for 3M nickel nitrate solution. In this study, the “homo-type catalyst” was defined that the metal distribution of catalyst inside pellet was homogeneous. The homo-type catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method with enough soaking time. Then, an evaporator was used to dry solvent used in metal salt solution. After metal salt impregnation, these pellets were dried at 150°C for 5h. Then, these alumina pellets with supported metal salt were calcined at 700°C for 4h. 2.3 Characterization of the adsorbents For the observation of metal salt diffusion inside alumina pellet, the cross-section images of spherical alumina pellet after impregnation were recorded on Dino-Lite Premier Digital Microscope (AM3113T, AnMo electronics), and the resultant images were processed using an image-processing software (DinoCapture 2.0, AnMo electronics). Using this software, the thickness of the shell, which contains metal salt or metal particles were measured. Scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JSM-7500F, JEOL) with EDS (energy dispersive spectroscopy, Oxford Instruments) was also used to analyze the change of metal concentration inside alumina pellet with line scan mode. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, OPTIMA 4300 DV, Perkin Elmer), installed at Korea Basic Science Institute, was used to measure the nickel loading of catalysts. The size of Ni particles supported on alumina pellets was analyzed by CO chemisorption using a BEL-CAT (MicrotracBEL) catalyst analyzer. Before analysis, samples were treated at 400°C in 5% H2/He gas for 3h. Temperature-programmed reduction was also measured by a BEL-CAT (MicrotracBEL) catalyst analyzer to investigate the reducibility of catalysts. 2.4 Steam methane reforming experiments For the steam methane reforming (SMR) reaction, catalyst pellets were packed with 20mm height in fixed-bed reactor with inconel (inner diameter=22mm). A thermocouple was inserted in the middle of catalyst pellets. Before SMR reaction, catalyst pellets were reduced in the 10% H2/N2 balance gas at 700 for 3h. Then, SMR reaction started. The steam to carbon ratio (S/CH2O/CH4) was 3.0. The steam was pre-heated at 450°C for stable supply. The reaction temperature was 700°C with different GHSV (gas hourly space velocity, 6000–30000h−1) for 50h. Product gas mixture obtained from SMR reaction was analyzed using gas chromatograph (3000 Micro GC Gas Analyzer, Inficon). Carrier gas was helium and Molsieve column was used for the analysis of H2, CO and CH4 and Plot U column was used for the analysis of CO2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Selective deposition of metal salts on spherical alumina pellet Fig. 1 not only shows the experimental procedure, but also, explains the concept of this study. In the first step, one selected hydrophobic solvent is introduced to alumina pellet. After hydrophobic solvent occupies void space inside the alumina pellet, an aqueous metal salt solution (nickel nitrate or cobalt solution) is added as a second step. The role of hydrophobic solvent is to retard the penetration of aqueous metal salt solution by the immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent and aqueous metal salt solution. In the third step, all the solvents are removed by drying to fix the position of metal salt inside alumina pellet. Based on this concept, various types of hydrophobic solvents and 0.5M cobalt nitrate aqueous solution were used to prepare egg-shell type catalyst indicating that metal salts are selectively located in the outer region of alumina pellet. As shown in the images of Table 1 , 0.5M aqueous cobalt nitrate solution penetrated inside alumina pellet completely within one minute without hydrophobic solvent. This is the reference condition for the impregnation of metal salt solution on alumina pellet. In case of selecting hexane or toluene as a hydrophobic solvent, only one minute was enough for 0.5M aqueous cobalt nitrate solution to completely penetrate inside alumina pellets. It means that hexane and toluene are not a proper hydrophobic solvent to retard the diffusion of aqueous metal salt solution inside pores of alumina pellet. When propanol was selected as a hydrophobic solvent, however, the penetration of cobalt nitrate solution was effectively retarded. The penetration of cobalt nitrate salt was not completed even after 30min. Considering the degree of miscibility between hydrophobic solvent and aqueous solution, toluene and hexane, which have lower solubility for aqueous cobalt nitrate solution, should have been the better solvent to hinder the penetration of aqueous cobalt nitrate solution than propanol did. However, the experimental result indicates that propanol, which has a higher solubility for aqueous metal salt solution than toluene and hexane, successfully prevent the penetration of metal salt solution. The effective retardation by propanol mainly comes from the difference of molecular structure. Apart from toluene and hexane, propanol has a hydroxyl group (-OH). This group may have an appropriately interaction with the surface of the alumina pellet and thus can be fixedly kept in the pores. Thus, in the selection of hydrophobic solvent to retard penetration of the aqueous metal salt solution, not only hydrophobicity but also the interaction between solvent and the surface of support should be considered. Similar approach was also applied in previous report. In the preparation of egg-shell catalyst using silica pellet support, n-heptane [16] was used as an effective blocking solvent to prevent the diffusion of aqueous cobalt nitrate solution. In that report, the interaction between n-heptane and silica surface was managed by maintaining the hydrophobic nature of silica surface with thermal treatment and subsequent careful storage in dry condition before cobalt solution impregnation. In this study, when using alumina pellet as a catalyst support, selection a series of alcohols as a hydrophobic solvent is much easier and simpler method to prepare egg-shell type pellet catalysts. In addition to cobalt nitrate, nickel nitrate solution was selected as an aqueous metal salt solution to prepare egg-shell type catalysts of nickel-supported on alumina pellet for steam methane reforming. As shown in images of Fig. 2 (a), the penetration depth of nickel nitrate solution in the image of alumina pellet cross-section was measured by the following way. “R” means the radius of alumina pellet. “R-r” implies the penetration depth. Thus, “(R-r)/R” indicates the radial portion occupied by nickel nitrate solution. When the “(R-r)/R” reaches 100%, it signifies that nickel nitrate solution completely occupied alumina pellet. Fig. 2(b) showed the change of the (R-r)/R depending the contact time and the concentration of nickel nitrate solution. In this experimental condition, hexanol was used as a hydrophobic solvent to retard the penetration of nickel nitrate solution. When 1M nickel nitrate solution was used, hexanol retarded the penetration of nickel nitrate solution down to 30% of (R-r)/R value within 60min. As the concentration of nickel nitrate solution increased to 3M, the penetration depth increased for every given contact time. The difference of concentration is expected to be a driving force of diffusion. Considering the formation of egg-shell type catalyst, low concentration of metal salt is preferred. For the preparation of high nickel loading in catalyst, however, high concentration of nickel nitrate should be used. For the preparation of egg-shell type catalysts with high nickel loading, the concentration of nickel nitrate solution was fixed to 3M. In this condition, various kinds of alcohols were used as a hydrophobic solvent to retard the penetration of nickel nitrate solution, as shown in Fig. 3 . Ethanol and propanol were not effective for preventing penetration of 3M nickel nitrate solution because nickel nitrate solution completely occupied alumina pellet within 30min. However, butanol, pentanol, hexanol, heptanol, and octanol firmly blocked the diffusion of nickel nitrate solution toward the center of alumina pellet. The enhancement of retarding nickel nitrate solution is mainly attributed to the improvement of hydrophobic nature of corresponding alcohol by the increase of carbon chain length from C2 (ethanol) to C8 (octanol). Based on this result, octanol was selected as a hydrophobic solvent to prepare egg-shell type Ni/Alumina catalyst for steam methane reforming. 3.2 Characterization of egg-shell-type pellet catalyst Homo-type 4.8wt.% Ni/alumina and egg-shell type 5.0wt.% Ni/alumina were prepared to compare the distribution of nickel particles supported on alumina pellet. The loading of nickel was confirmed by ICP-AES. As shown in Table 2 , the average nickel particle size of homo-type catalysts obtained by CO chemisorption was 34nm. That of egg-shell type catalyst was 26nm. It means that these two catalysts contained nickel particles with similar sizes. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) spectrum for homo-type and that for egg-shell-type was almost the same. (data not shown in this manuscript) Such similar TPR spectra indicate that the reducibility of homo-type catalyst and that of egg-shell type catalyst were almost the same. As shown in Fig. 4 , nickel concentration was measured by SEM-EDS in the cross-section of the alumina pellet from edge to center. For homo-type 4.8wt.% Ni/alumina, the concentration of nickel was almost the same in entire alumina pellet. It means that nickel particles were uniformly distributed on entire pellet. For egg-shell type 4.9wt.% Ni/alumina, however, the concentration of nickel in outer region of pellet was much higher than that in center of pellet. Considering the detection limit of EDS, the nickel concentration in the center of pellet was almost zero. It strongly suggests that nickel particles were selectively located in the outer region of alumina pellet in egg-shell type 4.9wt.% Ni/alumina. 3.3 Egg-Shell catalyst for steam methane reforming To examine the change of catalytic activity for nickel distribution in alumina pellet, homo-type 5.0wt.% Ni/alumina and egg-shell type 4.9wt.% Ni/alumina were used as catalysts for steam methane reforming depending on space velocity from 6000 to 30,000h−1. A commercial catalyst for steam methane reforming (FCR-4, Süd-chemie Catalysts Inc.,) was used as a reference catalyst. Fig. 5 displays the effect of metallic nickel particles distribution in the alumina pellet on the catalytic activity according to the space velocity. At lower space velocity of 6000h−1, three kinds of catalysts (FCR-4, egg-shell type Ni/alumina, Ni, homo-type Ni/alumina) showed almost the same CH4 conversion. As the space velocity increased up to 30,000h−1, all the CH4 conversions decreased gradually. The CH4 conversion of egg-shell type Ni/alumina was higher than that of homo-type Ni/alumina at this high space velocity condition (30,000h−1). Allowing for these two catalysts have the almost the same nickel loading (∼5wt.%) and used the same alumina pellet as support, the difference of conversion is mainly attributed to the distribution of metallic nickel particle inside alumina pellet. As confirmed in the previous catalysts characterization, the nickel particles were selectively located on the outer region of spherical pellet in egg-shell type Ni/alumina. At high space velocity condition (30,000h−1), the contact time between reactant and catalytically active site was too short for reactant to penetrate into the center of pellet. To effectively use catalytically active component, nickel particles should be located in the outer region of pellet. The effective usage of nickel was also confirmed by the comparison between FCR-4 and egg-shell type Ni/alumina. The decrease of CH4 conversion from low space velocity (6000h−1) to high space velocity (30,000h−1) for commercial catalyst (FCR-4) was about 5% and that for egg-shell type Ni/Alumina was ca. 3.5%. Considering the difference of nickel loading (FCR-4 of 12wt.% vs. egg-shell type Ni/alumina of 5wt.%) nickel particles supported in alumina pellet in egg-shell type seem to be utilized very effectively. Thus, egg-shell type 4.9wt.% Ni/alumina is expected to be the ideal catalysts for reactions with high space velocity. 4 Conclusions A new method to prepare egg-shell type pellet catalysts was developed using immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent preoccupied inside pellet and aqueous hydrophilic precursor solution. Among various kinds of alcohols, higher carbon number alcohols (butanol to octanol) retarded the penetration of nickel nitrate solution effectively. Among these alcohols, octanol was selected as hydrophobic solvents. After drying solvents and proper thermal treatment (calcination and subsequent reduction) nickel particles were selectively located in the outer region of pellet. Due to this uneven distribution of nickel particles, the egg-shell type catalyst showed higher conversion of methane in steam methane reforming than homo-type catalyst at the space velocity increased from 6000 to 30,000h−1. coredata.dc:description: Egg-shell-type catalysts, in which active components were selectively located outer region of pellet, have been prepared to effectively utilize catalytically active components in the reactions with high gas-hourly space velocity conditions. We developed a new and facile preparation method for egg-shell catalysts using immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent preoccupied inside pellet and aqueous hydrophilic precursor solution. A series of alcohols, propanol, butanol, pentanol and so on, were used as hydrophobic solvents to retard the penetration of aqueous metal precursor solutions. After drying solvents and proper calcination and reduction, catalytically active components, metallic nickel particles, were selectively located in the outer region of pellet. Owing to the selective deposition of metallic particles, the egg-shell catalysts showed higher conversion of methane in steam methane reforming than homo-type catalysts, which has homogeneous distribution of metal particles on the entire range of pellet, as the space velocity increased from 6000 to 30,000h−1.
coredata.dc:title: Facile preparation of egg-shell-type pellet catalysts using immiscibility between hydrophobic solvent and hydrophilic solution: Enhancement of catalytic activity due to position control of metallic nickel inside alumina pellet
